It was a gray, rainy day as Stephanie maneuvered her parent's car through the fog and the puddles. She was on her way to work, and it was always at times like these that Stephanie thought of her paycheck and wondered if it was worth it. It was worth it, of course, or at least it would be. Stephanie had never really worried about how she was going to pay for college, but after some serious shake ups in her families finances, it was pretty clear that she'd have to pay her own way. This waitress job was the highest paying job she could find in this horrible economy, and even with all the overtime she worked (while still making time for school) it was apparent that she'd just barely be able to scrape together enough cash to pay for her first semester, and that was only if she kept up her current, nearly phenomenal work rate. So yeah, it was worth it, she decided. Then she hit a pot hole and frantically wondered if she'd have to pay to have the tire fixed, imagining what the cost would do to her "no room for error" financial plans. When the tire didn't deflate, she breathed a sigh of relief and kept on driving, asking herself the same question again and again.

As she pulled into the parking lot of the restaurant where she worked, she thought of the monotony of past work days and promised herself that today was going to be different. Little did she know just how different it would be.

14511.content:
Shutting the car down, Stephenie checked her watch before casually making her way towards the restaurant where she worked. It was called "Le Nu" and it was a pretty nice place for a chain restaurant. It had started off as a really fantastic french restaurant called "Le plat Nu" but then the owner got corporate sponsorship, they shortened the name, started opening up franchises in every state and eventually it transformed into just another TGI Fridays. When she really thought about it, it made her kind of sad. She wondered how the original owner might feel about what his creation had become. She sometimes thought that it might be nice to visit the original, authentic restaurant, but then she remembered why she took this job in the first place: the cash. Until she was less strapped, she'd just have to settle for left overs.

The train of thought reminded her of one important fact, however. They were getting a new supervisor today. Profits for the franchise had been going down recently, and she heard the managers whispering about an impending visit from some hotshot from corporate with some radical ideas for turning the store around. From what she heard, the so called hotshot was young, just out of college, but with a wall full of business degrees and a chip on her shoulder. Stephanie and the other girls didn't know quite what to think, but each and every one of them was afraid of losing her job, none more so than Steph herself.

As she entered the store, she passed by the other girls (the store only employed waitresses, never waiters) who were all lined up by the bar, all of them wearing the basic "Le Nu" uniform, a white dress shirt with bow tie, black suspenders and a knee length black skirt. It wasn't anything fancy, but it was fairly conservative, and, as a modest girl, Stephanie always appreciated that.. Steph waved to her co-workers before hanging up her coat and joining them in anticipating the arrival of their new boss. They didn't have to wait long.

The new girl, who introduced herself as "Lilly Motre" was a rather striking figure. The first thing that Stephanie noticed was that she was extraordinarily petite. A skinny little blonde creature with short hair, and round glasses, wrapped in a steel gray business suit and perched precariously upon a pair of high heels that didn't quite bring her up to Stephanie's own unimpressive eye level. She smiled as she introduced herself and shook everyone's hand, but after that it was all business.

"Well, lets not waste any more time." She said, dispensing with the pleasantries. "As I'm sure most of you know, I've been sent here because this franchise isn't bringing in money like it used to. There are many conventional ways to handle a situation like this, and most of them involve identifying waste, for example, over-staffing, and making appropriate cuts."

That last line made Stephanie freeze up, and she knew she wasn't the only one! Lilly continued.

"Fortunately for you, however, the decrease in revenue is not limited to this one franchise, but endemic to the chain as a whole. For that reason, I have been authorized by the company to try some rather radical tactics to boost our cash intake. Think of it as a trial run, an experiment. If the tactics we spearhead here are successful, they will be put into effect in all Le Nu restaurants nationwide! That may not excite most of you the way it does me, but this is my area of expertise. This may be my first real life project of this kind outside of academia, but I assure you all that I know what I'm doing, and I will absolutely do everything in my power to make my changes successful. Some of them may seem strange to you at first, but I promise you that if you work with me, you will be rewarded for it with generous salary increases. If, however, you show yourself to be a problem... you will be removed immediately, without question or hesitation."

Stephanie liked the sound of those salary increases. Just about everything else on the other hand... not so much.

"So, now that you've all been properly appraised of the situation, lets get on to explaining those changes I was telling you about. There are going to be some new rules around her from now on, but first, I'd like to present to you one of the most important features of my new business plan: Operation: Renaissance!"

With that, she produced a box labeled "New Uniforms." Steph gulped visibly. While wondering what was inside the box, she couldn't help but imagine the worst.

"But... Ms. Morte..." Sandra a shy and somewhat chubby brunette muttered. "Where are we supposed to change? It's not like we have a locker room or anything..."

She was right about that. Thats why everybody showed up in their uniform in the first place. Most of the restaurant was taken up by the wide open seating area. The kitchen was small and cramped, and the bathrooms were even smaller.
